A work very much conducing to the more easie and speedy attaining of the Latin tongue; and to the saving of the labour of so frequently turning over voluminous dictionaries. By E.P. de Lond.

titleStmt.title: A treatise of the way and manner of forming the derivatives of the Latin tongue with a brief discourse of composites and de-composites. A work very much conducing to the more easie and speedy attaining of the Latin tongue; and to the saving of the labour of so frequently turning over voluminous dictionaries. By E.P. de Lond.
titleStmt.author: Phillips, Edward, 1630-1696?

publicationStmt.publisher: printed for the author, and are to be sold by George Croom, at the Blue-Ball in Thames-street,

Caption title on pg. 1: Of the way and manner of forming the derivatives of the Latin tongue, &c.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A TREATISE OF THE Way and Manner Of Forming the DERIVATIVES OF THE LATIN TONGUE: WITH A Brief Discourse of Composites and De-Composites.
A Work very much conducing to the more easie and speedy attaining of the Latin Tongue; and to the saving the labour of so frequently turning over Voluminous Dictionaries.
By E. P. de LOND.
LONDON, Printed for the Author, and are to be Sold by George Croom, at the Blue-Ball in Thames-street. 1685.
Licenced

Principibus Scholarum LONDINENSIUM, Caeterarum
que in Anglia, Nobiliorum, Gymnasiarchis Doctrina Celeberrimis, viz. WESTMONASTERIENSIS, Paulinae, Mercatorum Scissorum, Nec non Etonensis WINTONIENSIS, Salopiensis, Sitomagensis, &c. Hanc Elucubratiunculam D. D. D.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
FOr the perfect acquiring of any Language whatsoever there are two things mainly required, First to be acquainted in some Measure with the Words of the said Language, Next to understand how to put them together in such sort, as thereby to produce Harmonious Sense and Concord: The right way of putting Words together Effectually, is by the Variation of them; Nouns into their several Cases, Verbs into their several Moods and Tenses; For as in Building▪two pieces of Timber cannot be well fastned together till the Artists Tool hath fitted and shap'd them to that purpose, by Dovetail, Tenon and Mortice, or the like, so no true Syntax can be brought about, till by the said Variation Words are disposed together, in such a form as may render them Capable of such a Conjunction: Whereas, were they Clap'd together unform'd, and Undeclin'd, what could be expected but a Babel of Confusion and Discord? The Ancients, at least the Greeks and Latins were wonderfully Elaborate and Careful in the diversifying, or Variously terminating the Cases of their Nouns: From whith curious diversity of Terminations, there results an Elegance of Construction, above what even the best of the Modern Europaen Tongues, (wich I take to be the Italian) is capable of Expressing. And besides this Curiosity of Declination amongst the Greeks and Romans, the manner of their Derivation and Composition is also very Observable, and worthy to have been more Largely
Treated of, among other parts of Grammatical Subject, than I have yet found it to be, in any System of Grammar: Whereupon having already Publish'd a Materia Verborum, I have Adjoyned this small Treatise by way of Essay, which as occasion serves, may be Improv'd and Inlarg'd. The knowledge then of Words whether Primitive, Derivative, or Compositive, is to be doubly considered, First as to their Signification, Next their Formation; and the first of these Knowledges, in my Opinion, is properly and Naturally the first part of a Learners Office, contrary to the Common Method, since the Knowledge of the Name of any thing is ever antecedent to the knowledge of its Nature. He that hath Treasured up in his Memory a competent stock of Words, will be the more easily induc'd to take pains to inform himself of what ever may conduce to the Application of them, as any one will sooner ingage himself in the Concernments of a familiar and known Person, than of a Stranger. Dictionaries we have many, very Elaborate and Copious; more Copious indeed than what is absolutely required for a Learner; it being most apparently evident that one third part of the Words, even of the most Unaugmented Dictionaries, will abundantly suffice for the Reading of any Classical and Authentick Author; besides that, not any one can be capable of making use of a Dictionary, that is not Tollerably vers'd in the Formation of Words. So that a well ordered Materia Verborum to be got without Book, whether according to the usual Method of the Nomenclatura's, or otherwise, ought in my Opinion to be the first Praeparatory Work to be began with, as a Foundation for the Building up of a Latinist, or any other Master of Language: But for the gaining of a good stock of Latin Words, there cannot certainly be any better Course taken, than a full and perfect Acquisition of all the Radical and Underiv'd, at least such as are purely and Naturally Latin: For tho perhaps they amount not one with another, to the tenth part of those
Genuine Words produc'd by Derivation and Composition which often Occurring in Authors, are therefore Materi • and Necessary to be known. Yet certain it is, that whoeve • possesseth the Fountains, hath the greater Command and Benef •• of the Streams that flow from thence. So that he that i • Master of the Primitives, hath at one View the Lati • Tongue, and will be thereby the more easily induc'd, an • the better Capacitated to Consider and Inquire into the manner of how any Word he chances to meet with is Deriv'd fro • or Compounded with a Word he already Knows, as he w •• at a Distance hath the prospect of any Noble Castle; Town or Palace, will have the greater Mind by a Personal Visi • to take a more particular View thereof. To speak farther o • the Usefulness of this Design, will be a thing altogether nee •
less: One Evidence by plain Proof, goes farther than an hu •
dred Arguments. I will therefore leave the Event of wh •• I have Asserted to the Tryal the World may, if it please, ma •• thereof.

div.head: OF THE Way and Manner Of forming the DERIVATIVES OF THE LATIN TONGUE, &c.
div.p: The Derivatives of the Latin Tongue are very Various, both as to their Extraction and way of Forming, and proceed either from Verbs from Participles; (which are indeed themselves no other than Adjectives, Derived from Verbs.) from Nouns both Substantive and Adjective. From Adverbs: And lastly from Praepositions.

div.head: Nouns Substantive Derived from Verbs, signifying Persons] Verbals in Or, from Verbs of the First Conjugation.

list.item: A Mator oris. m. a Lover.
Salvator oris. m. A Saviour, &c. From Amo, Creo, Oro, Salvo.

div.head: From Verbs of the Second Conjugation.

list.item: Tonsor oris. m. A Barber, &c. From Doceo, spondeo, suadeo, Tondeo, &c.

div.head: From Verbs of the Third Conjugation.

list.item: Scriptor oris A Writer. From Duco, Lego, Pingo, Scribo.

div.head: From Verbs of the Fourth Conjugation.

list.item: Punitor oris m. A Punisher. From Audio, Condio, Munio, Punio.

div.head: Other Noun Substantives in Or, which seem not Derived from, but Coordinate with their respective Verbs.

list.item: Sudor oris. m. Sweat. Relating to Amo, Clamo, Erro, Sudo.
Timor oris. m. Fear. Relating to Doleo, Pudet, Splendeo, Timeo.
Tremor oris. m. A Trembling. Relating to Ango, Clango, Furo, Tremo.

div.head: Female Verbals, in the nature of Adjectives in Ix▪

list.item: Peccatrix. icis. f. A. She Sinner.
Venatrix icis. A. Huntress. From Oro, Pecco, Salto, Venor.
Auctrix icis. f. She that Increaseth.
Motrix icis. f. Capeable of Moving.
Tutrix icis. A Tutress. From Augeo, Moveo, Neo, Tueor.
Genitrix icis. She that giveth Birth.
Retentrix icis. Retaining. From Alo, Vinco, Gigno, Retineo.
Largitrix icis. she that Bestoweth. From Audio, Condio, Invenio, Largior.
Oratio onis. f. An Intreating, or making a Speech.
Tentatio onis. F. A Trying. From Creo, Oro, Purgo, Tento.
Motio onis. F. A Motion or Moving.
Sponsio onis. F. A Promising or Betrothing.
Repletio onis. F. A Filling. From Augeo, Moveo, Spondeo, Repleo.
Connexio onis. A Knitting together. From Lego, Defendo, Divido, Connecto.
Sanctio onis. A Sanction or Establishing.
Eruditio onis. A Bringing up. From Sanctio, Invenio, Nutrio, Erudio.

div.head: Nouns in La, Deriv'd from Verbs.

list.item: Tutela ae. Safeguard From Medeor, Queror, Suadeo, Tueor.

div.head: Nouns in Monia.

list.item: Querimonia ae. F. a Complaining humour. From Alo, Parco, Queror.

div.p: But most are Deriv'd from Adjectives, as shall be Noted in due Place.

list.item: Molimen inis. an Indevouring, From Conor, Tento, Specio, Molior.

div.head: Nouns in Tum.

list.item: Responsum i. n. An Answer. From Mando, Delinquo, Praecipio, Respondeo.

div.p: But these seem Neuters of Participles, only taken Substantively.

list.item: Testamentum i. n. A Witnessing. From Condio, Munio, Suppleo, Testor.
Receptaculum A Receptacle. From Caeno, Crepo, Habito, Recipio.

div.head: Verbals of the fourth Declension in Us, are generally the same in Form with the Participles of the Praeterperfect tence, of those Verbsto which these Verbals belong. as

list.item: Apparatus us. m. A making Praeparation.
Odoratus us. m. A Smelling. From Conor, Oro, Apparo, Odoro.
Visus us. m. Sight. From Mordeo, Lugeo, Rideo, Video.
Captus us. m. A taking or Capacity.
Tactus us m. A Touching. From Capio, Duco, Tango.
Haustus. us m. A Drawing▪ a Draught.
Vestitus us. m. A Cloathing. From Audio, Haurio, Sentio, Vestio.

div.head: Nouns in Ura, like the Faeminine Gender, of Participles in Rus, which seem Deriv'd by adding Ra to the last Supine.

list.item: Creatura ae. f. A Creating. a Creature.
Ligatura ae. f. A Ligature, a Binding.
Signatura ae. f A Signature, a Signing. From Armo, Ligo, Signo.
Tonsura ae. f. A Shaving. From Misceo, Tondeo.
Tinctura ae. f. A Dying. from Findo, Lego, Tego, Tingo.
Saltura ae. f. A Leaping. From Metior, Salio.
Scatebra a Boiling over. from Lateo, Scateo. To which may be added
Scaturigo An Overflowing. From Compingo, Orior, Prurio, Scaturio.
Tonstrina a Barbers Shop. From Pinso, Tondeo.

div.head: Adjectives deriv'd from Verbs. Adjectives in Ans or Ens, Commonly call'd Parciples of the Praesent tense

list.item: Mutans Changing. From Amo, Armo. Clamo, Muto.
Movens Moving. From Jubeo, Video, Timeo, Moveo.
Quaerens Seeking. From Scribo, Dico, Credo, Quaero.
Sentiens Perceiving. From Condio, Munio, Haurio, Sentio.
Agilis Active. From Ago. To which may be added

div.head: Adjectives in Tus, Sus, and Xus, Commonly call'd Participles of the Praeter perfect Tense.
Adjectives in Rus, commonly call'd Participles of the Future in Rus.
Adjectives in Dus, commonly call'd Participles of Future in Dus.

list.item: Moribundus, ready to Dy. from Tremo, Morior.
Contiguus, Joining so close, as to Touch.
Continuus, Continued, or Continual. from Assideo, Contingo, Contineo.

div.head: In Aceus.
div.p: From Nouns of the first Declension. as

list.item: Testaceus, Crusted with Sheard or Shell.

div.head: In Aticus.
div.p: From Nouns of the first Declension. as

list.item: Villaticus, Living in a Village. from Aqua, Silva, Villa:

div.head: And somtimes from Greek Nouns of the third Decl. as

list.item: Traumaticus, belonging to a Wound. from Aenigma, Trauma.

div.head: Adjectives in Alis, from Nouns of the first Declension. as

list.item: Brumalis, Wintry. from Forma, Bruma: And somtimes from other Declensions. as

div.head: In Aneus.
div.p: From Nouns of the second Declension. as

div.head: From Nouns of the third Declension. as
div.p: From Adverbs which see in their Place.

div.head: In Anus.
div.p: From Gentilitious Nouns of the first Declension, and somtimes second Neuters. as

list.item: Tròjanus, Trojan, or of Troy. from Roma, Troja.

div.p: And somtimes from common Nouns of the third Declension.

div.head: In Aris.
div.p: From Nouns of the first Declension, by adding Ris to the final A. as

list.item: Particularis, Particular. from Luna, Stella, Tutela, Particula. Somtimes from Nouns of the second and third Declensions. as
Solaris, Solar. from Titulus, Exemplum, Sol. Also from Adjectives. as

div.head: In Arius.
div.p: In like manner from Nouns of the first Declension, as

list.item: Gemmarius, Dealing in Jewels. from Aqua, Sagitta, Gemma. And as often from Neuters in Um. as
Lignarius, Working in Wood from Aurum, Argentum, Ferrum, Lignum: the word Faber being added, besides Momentarius, Momentary. from Momentum
Aerarius, Working in Brass. from Aes.
Temerarius, Rash. from Temere. See more in the Adverbs.

div.head: In Atilis.
div.p: From Nouns of the first and second Declension, as.

list.item: Fluviatilis, Living in the River, from Aqua, Fluvius.

div.head: The rest from Verbs, which see in the Verbs.
In Ensis.
div.p: From Names of Towns and Cities of the first and second Declension. as

list.item: Eboracensis, of York. from Athenae, Parisii, Eboracum.

div.head: In Enus.
div.p: From Nouns of the first Declension. as

list.item: Terrenus, Earthly. from Terra. And from other Adjectives. as

div.head: Alienus, Belonging to another Man. from Alius.
In Estis
div.p: Two only. as

list.item: Agrestis, Rude. Wild. from Coelum, Ager.

div.head: In Esttis.
div.p: From Nouns both of the first and second Declension, as

list.item: Campestris, Belonging to the Field, from Terra, Sylva, Campus.

div.head: In Eus.
div.p: From first, 2d. in us, 2d. in Um, and 3d Declensions, by changing the a finalis of the Nominative, or the i finalis of the first Case so ending into Eus as.

list.item: Spineus, Belonging to a Sloe-Tree. from Spinus.
Ferreus, of Iron, from Aurum, Argentum, Ferrum.

div.head: In Icus.
div.p: From Words of the first, by turning a finalis into i, and adding Cus. Second and third Declensions, by adding Cus to the first Case, ending in i.

list.item: Lyricus, Lyrick, sung or play'd to the Harp. from Aula, Lyra.
Ponticus, of the Sea. from Dominus, Pontus.
Magneticus, belonging to the Load-stone, Attractive. from Civis, Magnes.

div.head: In Inus.
div.p: From Words of the first Declension, seconds in Us, (Neutrals) in Um, and 3ds. as

list.item: Uterinus, belonging to the Womb. from Cervus, Fagus, Uterus.
Sesaminus, belonging to the Herb Sesamum. from Sesamum.
Vulpinus, belonging to a Fox. from Canis, Vulpes.

div.head: In Ruus.
div.p: From words of the third Declension, ending in r, by adding nus after r. as

list.item: Acernus, made of Maple. from Ebur, Acer.

div.p: To which may be added, by throwing away the last Sylable, and adding nus to the first in r.

list.item: Quernus, made of Oak From Quercus.

div.head: In Lentus.
div.p: From Nouns of the second, (both Us and Um) and third Declensions, Variously deriv'd. as

list.item: Sanguinolentus, Blooddy. from Corpus, Lux, Pulvis, Sanguis. Somtimes from Adjectives, of which hereafter.

div.head: In Orius.
div.p: From Verbal Substantives in Or. as

div.head: In the third Conjugation.

list.item: Scriptorius, given to Write. from Amator, Orator, Monitor, Suasor, Scriptor.

div.p: To which may be added,

list.item: Uxorius, addicted to a Wife. from Uxor.

div.head: In Osus.
div.p: From Nouns of the first, second, third and fourth Declensions, by changing a or i finalis into o, and adding Sus; or by adding the said Syllable to the first Case, ending in o. as

list.item: Paludosus, full of Puddles. from Caligo, Palus.
Portuosus, full of Havens, or Harbours.
Saltuosus, full of Woods. from Portus, Saltus

div.head: In Ivus.
div.p: See Adjectives, Deriv'd from other Adjectives or Participles.

div.head: In Tas.
div.p: From Nouns in Us impurum, and Uus, by adding the said Syllable to the first Case, ending in i. as

list.item: Assiduitas, Assiduity. from Probus, Curiosus, Assiduus.

div.head: In Nouns in Ius, i is changed into e. as

list.item: Honestas, Honesty. from Honestus. Us being only changed into As.

div.head: From Adjectives in Alis, by Adding Tas to the Dative, (now the first Case in i) as before the Genitive. as
From Verbal Adjectives and others, in Ilis, by the same manner of Deriving. as
In the second Conjugation.
div.p: Docilitas, aptness to be taught▪

div.head: In the third.
div.p: Agilitas, Agilitie. from Docillis, Agilis.

div.head: So likwise from Verbal Adjectives, in Abilis, and Ibilis. as

list.item: Flexibilitas, Flexibility, a • aptness to Bend. from Mutabilis, Flexibilis.

div.head: In Tudo.
div.p: From Nouns both in Us and Is, by adding Tudo to the first Case ending in i. as

list.item: Similitudo, Similitude. from Amarus, Fortis, Similis.

div.head: In Tas and Tudo both.
div.p: In like manner, from Nouns in Us. as

list.item: Celsitas and Celsitudo, Highness. from Beatus, Celsus.

div.head: In Edo.
div.p: From Nouns both in Us, and Is, by changing the i of the first Case so ending, into e, and adding Do. as

div.head: In Antia and Entia.
div.p: From Participles of the Present Tense, or such like Adjectives, in Ans or Ens, by adding a to the Dative Case, ending in Ti. as

list.item: Prudentia, Prudence. from Constans, Temperans, Diligens, Prudens.

div.head: In Acia.
div.p: From Adjectives in Ax, only by adding a to the Dative Case. as

list.item: Pervicacia, Stubbornness from Audax, Fallax, Pervicax.

div.head: In Itia.
div.p: From Adjectives in Us and Is, by adding Tia. to the i of the first Case so ending. as

list.item: Tristitia, Sadness. from Amicus, Justus, Tristis.

div.head: In Ities.
div.p: After the same Manner. as

list.item: Canus: And more frequently in both. as
Pigritia and Pigrities, Slothfulness. from Durus, Niger, Piger.

div.p: Not much different are those other Nouns

div.head: In Ia.
div.p: Which coming from Adjectives in Us, have only a added to the Final i of the Genitive Case. as

div.head: To which may be added some of uncertain Origination. as
In Go.
div.p: From Nouns of the second in Um, and third Declensions. as

list.item: Farrago, a mixture of several sorts of Grain.
Aerugo, Rust of Brass▪ from Far, Ferrum, Aes.

div.head: In Arium.
div.p: From Neuters of the second and from the third Declension.

list.item: Armentarium, a Store-house▪ from Aes, Alveus, Arma, Armenta.

div.head: In Erium.
div.p: From Nouns of the second Declension in Er, only by adding Ium.

list.item:
Ministerium, Ministry Service.
from Adulter, Minister.

list.head: To which may be added,
list.item: Arbitrium, Arbitrement, Will and Pleasure. from Arbiter.

div.head: In Are or Ar.
div.p: From Nouns of the first and second Declension, by adding re or r, to the final a it self, or so chang'd from i

list.item: Laquear, a Roof. from Cochlea, Palea, Alveus, Laqueus.

div.head: In Abulum, and Ibulum.
div.p: From first and Neuters of the second and third Declension but not always from Nouns, somtimes from Verbs. as

list.item: Infundibulum, a Funnel. from Acetum, Cunae, Thus, Tintinnio, Infundo.

div.head: In Brum.
div.p: Not always from Nouns, but somtimes also from Verbs.

list.item: Ventilabrum, a Winnowing Fan. from Candela, Ventilo.

div.head: In Aculum.
div.p: Senaculum, a Senate House. from Senatus.

div.head: In Ile.
div.p: From Nouns of the first, second and third Declensions.

list.item: Ovile, a Sheep-fold. from Hasta, Equus, Ovis.

div.head: In Ina.
div.p: From Nouns of the second and third Declensions, by adding na to the first Case ending in i. as

list.item: Farina, Meal. from Gallus Frater, Far.

div.head: In Orium.
div.p: From verbal Substantivs in o • , by adding only um to the Dative Case. as

list.item: Diversorium, an Inn. from Auditor, Diversor.

div.p: The rest are those which are call'd Diminutives, of which there is subjoyned a particular Discourse.

div.head: In Ivus.
div.p: By adding Vus to the final i of the first Case so ending. as

list.item: Solutivus, Solutive. from Lenitus, Positus, Solutus.

div.head: In Lentus.
div.p: From Adjectives of the first and second Declension, by an uncommon way of Derivation. as

div.head: In Or.
div.p: Comparatives, deriv'd from their Positives, both of the second and third Declension, by adding Or to the first Case ending in i. as

list.item: Mollior, more Soft. from Frigidus, Pulcher, Mollis.

div.head: In SSimus.
div.p: Superlatives deriv'd from their Positives, by adding SSimus to the first Case in i. as

list.item: Dulcissimus, Sweetest. from Altus, Jucundus, Dulcis.

div.head: In LLimus.
div.p: Other Superlatives, formed from their Positives in Lis, by changing Lis into Limus. as

list.item: Facillimus, most Easte. from Humilis, Similis, Gracilis.

div.head: In Errimus.
div.p: Other Superlatives formed from their Positives, in Er, only by adding Rimus, as

list.item: Tenerrimus, most Tender. from Pulcher, Celeber, Tener.

div.head: Besides these of a peculiar Form. as
div.p: The rest are Diminutives, which will soon after be treated of a part.

div.head: Substantives Deriv'd from Adverbs, and variously Form'd. as

list.item: Vicissitudo, Vicissitude. from Satis, Temere, Vicissim.

div.head: Adjectives deriv'd from Adverbs, by various manners of Formation. as

list.item: Nimius, Overmuch, from Cras, Hodie, Prope, Sponte, Nimis.
Superus, Supremus or Supernus, Supernal, or being Above.
Ultimus, Last. from Extra, Inter or Intra, Infra, Super or Supra, Ultra.

div.head: Verbs deriv'd from Nouns Substantive, by various manners of Formation.
In No.
div.p: From Nouns in Men. as

list.head: To which add
list.item: Criminor, to Blame. from Fulmen, Lumen, Semen, Crimen.
Advesperascit, it grows towards Evening. from Puer, Senex, Vesper. See Verbs deriv'd from Verbs,
Patrisso, to have the Fathers Garb, Actions, or Condition.
Platonisso, to follow Plato. from Pater, Plato.

div.head: And some which seem to saver more of Latin. as

list.item:
Bacchor, to live like a fol
•• wer of Bacchuso
Vulpinor, to have the tricks of a Fox.
Febricito, to be sick of a Feaver. from Febris.
Gruo, to cry like a Crane.
Salio, to season with Salt. from Grus, Sal.
Claudico, to Halt or go Lame.
Albico, to be White. from Claudus, Albus.
Graecor, to imitate the Greeks. from Graecus.
Mollio, to Soften. from Lenis, Mollis.
Demento, to make Mad. from Debilis, Demens:
Itero, to Iterate. from Cras, Satis, Prope, Iterum.

div.head: Verbs from Prepositions, by only adding O, and somtimes casting away E. as

list.item: Intro, to Enter. from Super, Inter.

div.head: Frequentatives in To, So, Xo. as

list.item: Canto, to Chant, to Sing often.
Visito, Viso, to Visit, to See often.
Nexo, to Knit. from Cano, Video, Voco, Necto.
Cantito, to Chaunt often. from Canto.
Tepesco, to wax Luke Warm▪ from Frigeo, Nigreo, Tepeo▪

div.head: Meditatives, or Desideratives. In Urio. as

list.item: Parturio, to be ready to bring Forth.
Scripturio, to have an itch of Scribling. from Edo, Pario, Scribo.
Vritim, Man by Man. from Grex, Pars, Vir.

div.head: In like manner they are deriv'd from Verbs. as
Adverbs from Nouns Substantive and Adjective.
In Tus.
div.p: From Nouns of the second, both Masculine and Neuter, and third Declension, by adding Tus to the I final of the first Case so ending. as

list.item: Radicitus, by the Roots, from Fundus, Antiquus, Coelum, Radix.

div.p: Adverbs derived from Adjectives only, most frequently

div.head: In E.
div.p: From Adjectives of the first and second Declension, by changing the Masculine Termination, Us into E. as

list.item:
Strenue, Stoutly. from Doc
• us, Jucundus, Strenuus.

div.head: In O.
div.p: In like manner deduc'd from the same sort of Adjectives.

list.item: Sedulò, Diligently. from Meritus, Fortuitus, Sedulus.

div.head: In Ter.
div.p: From Adjectives of the third Declension, in is and ns as

list.item: Eleganter, Elegantly▪ from Fortis, Lenis, Diligens, Elegans.

div.head: In Rsum.
div.p: From Adjectives in Er, of the second Declension, by adding Rsum to the final O, of the first Case. as

list.item: Sinistrorum, towards the Left. from Dexter, Sinister.

div.head: Im Um.
div.p: From Adjectives of the first and second Declension, whose Masculines are in Us. as.

list.item: Tantum, Only. from Durus, Horrendus, Tantus.

div.p: But these seem only the Neuter Genders of the said Adjectives, taken Adverbially.

div.head: So likwise in E.
div.p: From Adjectives of the third Declension, whose Masculine and Faeminine Termination, is Is. as

div.head: Diminutives.
div.p: Of the Diminutives of the Latin Tongue Great are the Varieties and admirable the Elegancies.
Diminutives of Nouns Substantive.
In the first Declension. In Ula.

div.head: By interposing between the last Consonant, and the A Final Ula. as

list.item: Rotula, a little Wheel. from Gemma, Rima, Rota.

div.head: In Eola.
div.p: By interposing between the E and A Final O L. as

list.item: Ardeola, a little Heron. from Area, Aranea, Ardea▪

div.head: In Jola. as
div.p: Much after the same manner. from Fascia, Filia, Luscinia.

div.head: In Ella.
div.p: By a various manner of Extraction. as

list.item:
Faemella, a little Female.
from Capra, Catena, Fabula, Fenestra, Faemina.

div.head: In Illa.
div.p: Some words seem Diminutives, which are not so in reality, there being no certain Account to be given of their Origination. as

div.head: In Aster.
div.p: By adding Ster at the end. as

list.item: Poetaster, a dabler in Poetry. from Olea, Picea, Poeta.

div.head: In Unculus
div.p: One word only.

list.item: Ranunculus, a little Frog. odly Deriv'd from Rana.

div.head: In the second Declension, In Ulus.
div.p: From Nouns in Us, by interposing between the U and the S, L▪ U.

list.item: Servulus, a Valet▪ from Modus, Rivus, Servus.

div.head: In Illus.
div.p: By a various way of Derivation, from Nouns in Us of the second, and is of the third Declension. as

list.item: Pulvillus, a little Cushion. from Haedus, Baculus, Pulvis.

div.head: In Eolus.
div.p: From Nouns in Eus, by dividing Eus, and interposing Ol. as

list.item: Pileolus a little Cap. from Calceus, Malleus, Pileus.

div.head: In Iolus.
div.p: From Nouns also in Ius, and by the same manner of Interposition. as

list.item: Gladiolus a little Sword. Also Cornflag.
Modiolus, a small Measure. from Filius, Gladius, Modius.

div.head: In Unculus. as
div.p: See also in the third Declension.

div.head: Usculus.
div.p: Only by adding Culus.

list.item: Ramusculus, a little Branch. from Ramus.

div.head: In Ellus.
div.p: From Masculines in Er, by taking away r, and adding llus. as

list.item: Magistellus, a little Master. from Liber, Magister.

div.head: In Ulum.
div.p: From Neuters in Um, by interposing Lu between the u and m. as

list.item: Scutulum, a little Shield. from Frustum, Scutum.

div.head: In Illum.
div.p: By a more various way of Formation. as

list.item: Specillum, a Looking-Glass. from Baculum, Specium, or Speculum.

div.head: In Eolum.
div.p: by interposing Ol between e▪ and Um. as

list.item: Pileolum, a little Cap. from Horreum, Linteum, Pileum.

div.head: In Iolum.
div.p: By the same way of Interposition. as

list.item: Suaviolum, a little Kiss, also a Sweet-Heart.
Sudariolum, a little Handkerchief. from Mortarium,
Pinaster, a wild Pine-Tree. from Pinus.

div.head: In Iculus.
div.p: from non Crescents, Masculine for the most part in Is, by adding Culus to the Dative or fist Case ending in i. as

list.item: Folliculus, a small pair of Bellows. from Ensis, Ignis, Follis.

div.head: In Icula.
div.p: From non Crescents Faeminine, in Is and Es, by adding Cula, as aforesaid. as

list.item: Craticula, a Grid-Iron. from Avis, Navis, Crates.

div.head: In Ecula,
div.p: From Noncrescents in Es, only by removing the final S of the Nominative, and adding Cula. as

list.item: Vulpecula, a little Fox. from Abies, Nubes, Vulpes.

list.head: To which may be added, from Apes,
list.item: Apecula, and Apicula both, a little Bee.
Plebecula, the lowest rank of People.

div.head: Also from grave Crescents in Ex, by a more extraordinary way of Formation.

list.item: Forficula, a little pair of Scissers. from Cortex, Forfex.

div.head: In like manner from acute Crescents in Ix. as
In Alculum.
div.p: By only adding Culum to Al.

list.item: Animalculum, a little Creature. from Animal.

div.head: In Iculum▪
div.p: In like manner as those in Icula. as

list.item: Apiculum, a little Tuft or Peak. from Apex, acute Crescent.

div.head: In Orculus.
div.p: From Verbals in Or, by adding Culus, as

div.head: In Uncula.
div.p: From Verbals in Tio, by removing the final O, and adding Uncula, as

list.item: Oratiuncula, a small Harangue, or Oration. from Aratio, Oratio.

list.head: To which may be added
list.item: Legiuncula, a little Legion. from Imago, Legio.

div.head: In Unculus.
div.p: Chiefly from Nouns in o, by removing the final o, and adding Unculus. as

list.item: Latrunculus, a Hedge-Padder. from Homo, Latro.

list.head: To which may be added
list.item: Furunculus, a little Thief. from Fur, a Thief.

div.p: See also in the first and second Declension.

div.head: In Usculum.
div.p: For the most part from Grave Crescent Neuters in Us, only by adding Culum to the final Us. as

list.item: Opusculum, A little Work. from Corpus, Munus, Opus.

div.head: In Icula, and Iculus.
div.p: by removing the final Us, and adding in Words of the Foeminine Gender Icula, in those of the Masculine Iculus. as

list.item: Versiculus, a little Verse from Acus, Anus, Versus.

div.head: In Iculum.
div.p: From Neuters of the same Declension, by removing the final u, and adding Iculum, as

list.item: Geniculum, a litle Knee. from Cornu, Genu.

div.head: In Ecula.
div.p: By casting away S, and adding Cula. as

list.item: Recula, a small Matter, or Estate.
Specula, small Hope. from Res, Spes.

div.head: In Uncula.
div.p: Only One.

list.item: Speciuncula, a little Image. from Species

div.head: Diminutives of Nouns Adjectives.
div.p: These follow the same mode and form as Substantive Diminutives, according to the several Declensions to which they are Reducible. as

list.item: Molliculus, somwhat Soft. from Grammaticus, Parvus, Pulcher, Mollis.

div.p: But some peculiar Diminutives there are, viz.

div.head: In Aculus, and Oculus.
div.p: From Adjectives in Ax and Ox, by removing the final X, and adding Culus. as

list.item: Feroculus, somewhat Fierce. from Audax, Loquax, Ferox. Also

div.head: In Usculus.
div.p: From the Neuters of Comparative Degrees, by adding Culus. as

list.item: Molliusculus, somwhat Softer. from Durius, Melius, Mollius.

div.head: Diminutives of Verbs. In Illo.
div.p: By putting Ill before the final O, and in the second Conjugation removing E. as

list.item: Sorbillo, to Sip. from Canto, Sorbeo.

div.head: Diminutives of Adverbs In Um.
div.p: These are commonly the Diminutives of Adverbs, deriv'd from Adjectives, and Formed by the same manner as the Adjectives, from whence they come. as

list.item: Tantillum, so little. from Paulum, Tantum, Quantum.

div.head: In Usculé.
div.p: From their Adjectives, diminish'd from the Neuters of Comparative Degrees. as

list.item: Molliusculé, somwhat more Softly. from Duriusculus,

list.head: To these may be added
list.item: Clanculum, somwhat Privately. from Clam, both Adverb and Praeposition, by chnging m into n, and adding Culum.

div.head: OF THE COMPOSITES Of the LATIN TONGUE.
div.p: THere was doubtless never any Language or Speech in any part of the World, to which there did not more or less, somthing of Composition belong, that is a sort of Coalition or Consociation of two or more Words together: But of all Languages that ever were Writ or Spoke, I verily believe the Greek first, and after that the Latin, have far the most▪ Elegant and Graceful way of Composition. Of the latter my purpose is to say somthing at present, with as much Brevity as may be.
Verbs, Nouns, Adverbs, Praepositions, are all Compoundable one among another, but the most common and frequent sort of Composition, is of Verbs with Praepositions.

div.head: Praepositions that admit of Composition with Verbs.

list.head: Whence
list.item: Detraho, to Detract, or take from.
Edormio, to sleep out or away.
Praetermitto, to let Goe beside, to pass by.
Transfero, to carry Over, to remove from one Place or thing to another.

div.head: Particles like Praepositions, join'd in Composition to Verbs.

list.item: Di or Dis, a Note of Division.
Ambigo, to be in Doubt about any Business.
Digero, to Digest, to carry into divers Parts.

div.p: Where it is to be observed, that Re coming before a Vowel, D is Interposed.
Sepono, to set Apart.

div.head: Verbs which in Composition change A into E.

list.head: Whence E. Gr.
list.item: Confercio, to Stuff or cram in
Delecto, to Delight, also to Allure.
Perpetro, to do a Business Throughly.
Ascendo, to Ascend, or climb Up.

list.head: There are also excepted from the former these few.

div.head: Verbs which in Composition change A, Ae or E, into I

list.item: Lego, to Read. Also to Gather.

list.head: Whence E. Gr.
list.item: Cohibeo, to Restrain, or hold Back.
Deliteo, or Delitesco, to lie Hid.
Emineo, to Stand or hang out.
Deprimo, to Depress, to press down.
Assilio, to Leap at, or against.
Despicio, to Look down upon, to Despise.
Attingo, to Touch upon, to attain to.

div.head: Several Compounds of some of the fore-going Verbs, which change not the Vowel A, viz.

list.item: From Pango, Depango, Circumpango, Oppango, Repango.

div.head: Compounds which changing in the Praesent Tense take back the Praeterper perfect Tense, and Supine of the Simple, viz.
Compounds which only change A into E in the Supine
Verbs which in Composition change A into U.
Verbs which in Composition throw out A and retain U.
Praepositions which in Composition change (but not always) their final Consonant.

list.head: Ab, which changes B into U before F. as

div.p: Before other Consonants or a Vowel or H changes not. as
Except before T, where S is added. as in

div.head: Abstraho

list.head: Ad which before c. f. g. l. n. p. r. s. t. for the most part changes the final D into the said Consonants, being the Initial Letters of the several Simple Verbs. as in

div.p: Some times we say Adfero, Adlatro, &c. Before q changes into, c. as
Before D. j Consonant. M. and V Consonant, or a Vowel or H, changes not. as in

list.item: Con (made of Cum) which before L and R changes in the same manner as Ad. as in

div.head: Before b and p, changes n. into m. as in
Before c. d▪ f. g. j. n q. s. t. v. changes not. as in
Before Nosco, n is changed into g. as

list.head: E and EX which only differ in this, that the first comes altogether before Consonants, the other before Vowels, H, and these following Consonants. p. s. t. as
list.item: Exsicco, (or Exicco, the S being oft times Included.) To Dry.

list.head: In which before l. m. r. changes as aforesaid▪ as in

div.head: Before c. d. f. g. j. n. q. s. t. a Vowel and h, changes not. as in
Before B and P changes N into M. as in
Before N somtimes changes into G. as in

list.head: Ob, which before c. f. (but not always) and p changes, as aforesaid, as
list.item: Oppugno, to Oppose, or Fight against.

div.head: Before other Consonants or a Vowel, changes not. as in

list.item: Obrepo, to Creep upon any one Unawars.
Obsigno, to set a Mark against
Ostendo, to Shew. Most probably from Ob and Tendo, wherein the change is Particular, of B and S.
Per, which changes only before L. as in

p.hi: Not before any other Consonant, or any Vowel. as

list.item: Peroro, to tell a Tale to an End, &c.
Pro, which before a Vowel hath always D Interposed. as

p.hi: Otherwise suffers no Alteration. as in

list.item: Prosum, to be Profitable; in all Persons and Tenses that begin with a Consonant.

list.head: Sub, which before c. f. g. m (somtimes) p. r. changes as aforesaid. as in

div.p: Where before c and p the B is changed into S.

div.head: Before d. j. l. n. s. t and v. changes not. as in

list.item: Subtraho, (or S being somtimes added) Substraho, to Draw away.
Suspicio, to Look up, to Honour, to Suspect.

div.p: Whence Suspicor, where B before the S is Lost.
Sustineo, to Sustain:
Whence Sustento.
Sustollo, to Lift up.
Where before T the B is▪ changed into S.
Trans, which before D. J. for the most part loosing its two last Consonants, is changed into Tra. as in
Befere c, p, or a Vowel changes not. as

div.head: Adverbs joined in Composition with Verbs.

item.hi: Verbals Passive and such like Derivatives from Verbs follow, in their Mode of Composition with Praepositions, Adverbs and Particles the Supines of the Verbs, from which they come. as

div.head: Participles Compounded of not Compounded Verbs.

list.item: Doceo, and Apiscor, not Compounded with In.

list.head: Original Substantives compounded with Praepositions. Inter, Ob, Prae, Pro Sub, Super.
list.item: Convallis, a Dale Inviron'd with Hills. from Con and Vallis.
Intervallum, a Space between the Stakes in a Trench.
Occiput, the hinder part of the Head.
Sublimen, the under part of the Threshold.

div.head: Adjectives compounded with Praepositions, In Per, Prae, and Sub. as
Particular Noun Substantives made of the composition of Praepositions, and Verbs.

list.item: Antefactum, a Deed foredone. from Ante, and Facio.
Congeries. a Heap. from Con and Gero.
Exidium Destruction. from Ex and Caedo.
Infundibulum, a Funnel. from In and Fundo.
Interstitium, a Place to stand Between.
Obstaculum, an Obstacle. from Ob and Sto.
Subsidium, Aid. from Sub and Sedeo.
Transfuga, a Revolter to the other Side. from Trans and Fugio.
Subterfugium, a Privy Escape. from Subter, and Fugio.

div.head: Particular Adjectives made of the composition, of Praepositions and Verbs.

list.item: Collectitius, gathered from many Sorts. from Con, and Lego.
Demonstrativus, Demonstrative. from De and Monstro.
Objurgatorius, pertaining to Chiding. from Ob and Jurgo.
Perfunctorius; Slightly done. from Per and Fungor.
Promiscuus, mix'd at Random. from Pro and Misceo.
Subdititius, put in Place of Another. from Sub and Do.
Transitorius, passing quick Away. from Trans and Eo.

div.head: Adverbs deriv'd from Adjectives follow the same form of Composition▪ as the Ad jectives, they came from. as
Noun Substantives, made of the composition of Praepositions, with Substantives. as

list.item: Antecoenium, a Drinking between Dinner and Supper. from Ante and Caena.
Interlunium, the space between each Change of the Moon.
Pomaerium, a space about a Town-Wall. from Post and Murus.

div.head: Adjectives made of the composition of Praepositions, with Substantives.

list.item: Antelucanus, done before Daylight▪ from Ante & Lux.
Decolor, changing Colour▪ from De and Color.
Extemporaneus, done without Study, or Meditation, from Ex and Tempus.
Inermis Unarmed. from In and Arma.
Perennis Continual. from Per and Annus.
Subdialis, Done, or being in the open Air.

div.head: Nouns Substantive and Adjective, made of the composition of Substantives, with Adverbs or Particles.

list.head: SUBSTANTIVES.
list.item: Biennium, the space of two Years. from Bis and Annus.
Non nihil, Somthing. from Non, and Nihil.
Semivir, half a Man. from Semis, and Vir.
Triduum, the space of three Dayes. from Ter and Dies.

list.head: ADJECTIVES.
list.item: Biceps, having two Heads. from Bis and Caput.
Biformis, having two Forms. from Bis and Forma.

div.head: Nouns made of the composition of Substantives, with Substantives.

list.head: ADJECTIVES.
list.item: Retiformis, being in the form of a Nett.

div.head: Nouns made of the composition of Adjectives, with Substantives.

list.head: ADJECTIVES.
list.item: Omniformis, Of all Forms or Shapes.

div.head: Nouns made of the composition of Substantives, with Verbs.

list.head: SUBSTANTIVES.
list.item: Lumbifragium, a Fracture about the Loins.
Solstitium, the time of the Sun's seeming to stand Still.

list.head: ADJECTIVES.
list.item: Odorifer, carrying any Smell, or Scent.

div.head: Nouns made of the composition of Adjectives, with Verbs.

list.head: SUBSTANTIVES.
list.item:
Multinuba, one that hath been
Married to Many.

div.head: Adjectives made of the composition of Verbs, with Substantives.
Nouns made of the composition of Adverbs, with Verbs.

list.head: ADJECTJVES.
list.item: Aequipolleo, to be of Equal Force and Vertue.
Olfacio, to give a Tast or Smell.

div.head: Adverbs compounded with other Adverbs, or with Praepositions.
OF DECOMPOUNDS.
div.p: DEcomposita, or Decompounds are Words Doubly Composite, or Compaunds Compounded: The Chiefest whereof are Verbs, doubly Compounded with Praepositions, besides those Participles, Substantives and Adverbs, which are Deriv'd from Verbs.

list.head: Verbs compounded with Praeposition upon Praeposition, or Particle.
list.item: Praeexisto, to have a Being before.

list.head: Substantives from Verbs.
list.item: Supererogatio, a giving more than is Required.

list.head: Compounds Decompounded with one Praeposition.
list.item: Imparisyllabicus, having not a like number of Syllables.
